Tools and Methods for Communicating Disaster Risks
Tools and Methods for Communicating Disaster Risks

Effective risk communication can help the public to understand potential risks and be able to prepare and respond to the increasing frequency and intensity of disasters.Students will investigate issues associated with risk reduction through “warning and informing”, such as public perception of risk and communicating risk messages effectively through awareness campaigns and education. The role and challenges of using social media in risk communication will be critically examined. To achieve this, the course will explore issues for public education and raising awareness. Hands-on session will be introduced to enhance students’ experiential learning.Indicative learning outcomes include: 1.Assess the factors that affect perception of risk held by practitioners and the public. 2.Explore the process of risk communication in both developed and developing worlds.3.Investigate effective tools and technologies to disseminate information about environmental risks.4.Examples of public awareness programmes including information sources and message characteristics.
Food Security and Rural Livelihoods in Disaster Contexts
Food Security and Rural Livelihoods in Disaster Contexts

This course is concerned with the interrelated issues of food security, prosperity and diversification of rural livelihoods, in disaster contexts which are considered central to the achievement of rural development.People gain their livelihoods in a variety of ways: from different types of farming to a wide range of other activities. They do so with varying degrees of success related to their capabilities, access to resources and employment and how they deal with pressure arising from social political, economic and environmental change. For organisations active in rural development it is of utmost importance to have a good understanding of the livelihoods of the target populations and their coping strategies in times of adversity.

Urbanisation has substantial impacts on the hydrology of cities including increased risk of flooding. This is due to increased imperviousness, removal of vegetation and the channelisation and canalisation of waterways. An introduction to the concept of Sustainable Drainage (SuDS) requires an understanding of these impacts, the reasons why flooding occurs and how SuDS can address these risks. Sustainable Drainage encourages the infiltration of excess surface water into the ground, its storage and slow conveyance to the receiving watercourse. In this way, it slows the flow, reduces flooding and at the same time provides water quality improvements and opportunities for amenity and wildlife. The approach is flexible and multiple benefit and this will be explored in terms of its ability to mitigate and adapt to climate change, address the Urban Heat Island Effect as well as other benefits such as the impacts of vegetated devices on perceptions of human health.The course will introduce the physical and chemical means by which SuDS can address these issues, the devices that are used, their design both in new build and retrofit, and also the challenges of designing the SuDS Management Train. Exemplars will be given from the UK, but also worldwide. By explaining case studies across the world, different climates will be covered and issues associated with them, such as disease vectors and their control using SuDS devices, an example will be the Zika virus, in Brazil, and BIOECODS from Malaysia which are designed to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes. Further challenges will be explored by examining issues in refugee camps, particularly in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq and informal settlements around Cape Town, South Africa. In the UK, Working With Nature (WWN) is a new and challenging concept, introducing the idea of Natural Flood Management which takes a whole catchment approach, starting in the headwaters, to address flood management downstream. One session will be practical and involve identifying opportunities for retrofitting SuDS in urban areas, and of installing NFM measures in rural environments. Finally, the concept of the “Sponge City” will be explored in detail to illustrate the whole city approach taken by China. Suining, Sichuan will be explored as this is one of the 16 Sponge Cities selected by the Chinese government. Suggested learning outcomes include:1.Critically assess the impacts of urbanisation on the hydrology and hydraulics of catchments. 2.Understand the four pillars of SuDS: in reducing water quantity; improving water quality; providing potential for amenity; providing potential for biodiversity.3.Assess the efficiency of SuDS in different climates and the flexible and multiple benefits of the approach.4.Understand the incorporation of SuDS into both new-build and retrofit, as well as the use of Natural Flood Measures in rural areas.Apply knowledge of SuDS to the Sponge City concept in China
Natural hazards: Cause, Effect and Solutions
Natural hazards: Cause, Effect and Solutions

Natural hazards have the potential to affect every person on Earth, regardless of nationality, race, wealth or level of education. In recent years, we have seen the impacts of such events rise, as population pressures have forced communities to live in hazardous locations and as the climate continues to change. Given such facts, it is important that younger generations are armed with relevant knowledge concerning such events and that is the aim of this course.The course will introduce a range of natural hazard events, ranging from geological hazards, such as earthquakes and volcanoes, to hydro-meteorological hazards such as hurricanes and floods. It will present the causes of such events, discussing the physical scientific processes that generate them and their interrelatedness, while also highlighting the role that societies have in compounding, or indeed in some cases, generating, their widespread impacts. The idea that “Earthquakes don’t kill, buildings do”, will also be explored, along with a consideration of hazardoccurrence frequency, magnitude and probability.Following a grounding in these fundamental topics, the concept of the ‘Disaster Management Cycle’ will be presented, focusing on what societies can do to either prevent, mitigate or predict future natural hazard events. Successful and unsuccessful examples of prevention, mitigation and prediction will be presented, with students also given the opportunity to develop their own early-warning messages. The course will end with a consideration of the future prospects for managing these natural, but often devastating, events, showing that we may never be able to stop them but that we might be able to reduce the tragic impacts they often have.The intended learning outcomes are that, on completion of this course, the student should be able to:1. Describe the physical processes associated with various natural hazards.2. Understand the interrelated nature of natural hazards.3. Appreciate that the effects of natural hazards are often the result of human activity or inactivity.4. Explain the different methods and the techniques for preventing, predicting and mitigating against natural hazards.

病理生理学是医学教育的一门主干学科， 是医务人员必须掌握的一门基础医学知识。病理生理学主要探讨疾病发生、发展的规律和机制，对这些规律和机制的深入认识不但有助于学生深入认识疾病，而且，由于近年来对疾病发生机制研究的飞速进展，病理生理学的内容更成为医学相关专业的学生和从业者跟上这种进展步伐的重要基础。学好病理生理学将显著拓宽医学生的视野，增强他们的后劲。病理生理学又是一门与多学科密切相关的桥梁性学科。它不仅与解剖学、组织学、遗传学、免疫学、生理学、生物化学、病理学等密切相关，而且与临床各科亦密切相关。病理生理学是连接基础医学与临床医学的一门过渡性学科。

：本课程是为基础医学本科生开设的必修专业基础课程，其目的是使学生认识生物医学科研的基本性质和任务，具备从事生物医学科研的基本素质，知晓科学研究的行为准则和规范。本课程需要学生了解生物医学科研设计与实施的基本原理和程序，掌握生物医学科研的基本方法和技能，熟悉生物医学实验的过程和内容，掌握国内外生物医学信息的收集和处理的基本方法，了解生物医学科研课题的申请和实施，提高生物医学科研论著的撰写能力以及熟悉国内外生物医学科研基金的概况和申请渠道等。本课程为初步涉足生物医学科研人员必不可少的入门课程，是一门具有创新性、理论和实践相结合的特色课程。

人体解剖学是研究人体正常形态结构的科学，医学教育中安排本课程的目的，在于使学生理解和掌握人体各器官的形态结构，配布形式及基本规律，为学习以后的基础课和临床课奠定必要的形态学基础。本课程主要是按局部解剖的方法来阐述人体各个局部内正常器官结构的形态、位置和相互的毗邻关系，以及各局部之间联系；通过学生对人体标本的实地解剖操作、观察、学习，获得人体形态结构的基本知识和一定的动手能力。

现代酶学中的酶基因工程技术是生命科学的一个分支，与其它学科联系紧密，是目前生命科学研究的前沿之一。本课程主要内容包括理论酶学和应用酶学两大部分。理论酶学部分包括酶的分类组成及结构特征、动力学、作用机制、活性调节、核酶与抗体酶、模拟酶、气体酶学、分子印迹酶、非水介质中的酶反应、细胞信号转导与酶、自由基与酶、组合生物催化及酶的定向进化等。应用酶学部分包括酶基因工程技术、酶的分离与纯化技术及酶的应用。本课程是在基础生物化学的基础之上开设的一门课程，目的是使学生能够把基础生物化学的理论知识和实际应用相联系，激发学生对基础课学习的兴趣，了解此领域的最新进展。

本课程面向医学和生命科学专业本科生开设。是在系统学习医学免疫学，具备一定的免疫学背景知识的基础上开设的专门介绍免疫学及其相关领域的最新进展和热点问题，以专题讲座的形式授课。目前讲授内容主要包括：细胞因子及其应用；基因工程抗体；树突状细胞（DC）；Toll 样受体信号传导途径；B7家族及其新成员；NK细胞表面受体；Thl7细胞分化和功能；调节性T细胞；肿瘤干细胞；黏膜免疫；过敏性疾病研究进展；艾滋病免疫学研究进展；自身免疫病研究进展；移植免疫研究进展，肿瘤免疫和免疫治疗研究进展等。该课程的目的是为医学和生命科学专业高年级学生传授免疫学前沿知识和介绍最新进展以激发他们对基础医学的兴趣和想象力。

皮肤疾病与健康是大学生特别是青春期常见的问题，皮肤非健康状态对学生的心里有不良的影响，对学生进行有关方面的教授，可以提高学生对自身皮肤健康的关注和科学的认识，同时减少因该方面知识的错误认识所带来的心理影响。本课程主要从三个方面讲授，一是皮肤的正常结构与功能。二是化妆品知识：化妆品的一般知识、药妆品、特殊功能化妆品以及有关化妆品的不良影响；化妆品的发展状况等。第三，皮肤疾病的防治：过敏性皮肤疾病、真菌感染性皮肤病、粉刺、色素沉着性疾病、湿疹性皮肤病、脱发等的防治。
